title: The Present Defines the Past
Show HN: Optioncharts.io – A charting platform for option investors
text:
Hi!
I created OptionCharts.io, a charting and visualization platform for option investors. With OptionCharts.io, you can easily view and analyze a range of important data, including volume, open interest, probability distribution, volatility skew, max pain, Greeks, option history, option profit/loss, and more. I created OptionCharts.io because I was looking for a comprehensive and modern charts for viewing option data and couldn't find one that had all these charts in one place that wasn't paywalled. I hope that OptionCharts.io will help other option investors make informed decisions by providing easy access to all of this important information in one place. If you have any feedback please let me know what you think!

Ask HN: Cable diameter required to handle web apps
text:
With the volume of messages on WhatsApp, images and videos on Instagram, tweets on Twitter, etc., what is the approximate diameter of the cables some of the main consumer services would require if all traffic were to pass through one cable.

This question is assuming: excessive technical details ignored, equally distributed loads throughout the day, worldwide traffic through one cable.

Bo need to get out your inspector hats for the question, looking for a rough estimate to visualize what underground cables are going through.

Ask HN: How to upgrade salary structure to keep existing team happy?
text:
I run a web design and engineering studio, and unlike many competitors, I don't want to increase headcount too much. I want to keep it small (under 30 people), lean and keep working on our collective craftsmanship. In other words I want to avoid selling man-days and inevitably an outsourcing company.

We've been fortunate to end up in a place where we can pay above market rates to work with the best people. However, If we suddenly pay 1.5x to someone who just joined, it will destroy morale across all existing team members.

Upgrading all salaries across the board at once sounds a bit naive to me as it might feel as a signal of being underpaid for long period of time before (or maybe not? Thinking out loud)

Would love to hear your opinions and experience if you came through similar growing issues where you want to double down on quality not quantity of people.

Thanks!

Ask HN: Risk of unsafe software in automobiles?
text:
I may buy a car (new or used) soon and am a little worried about all the software in cars these days. Software can control pretty much every aspect of a modern vehicle, and so the idea of bugs in a vehicle's software scares me from a safety perspective. Poor software engineering has been implicated in automobile safety incidents in the past[1].

I'm aware of the NASA/JPL rules for developing safety-critical software[2] but I'm not sure if any car manufacturers follow anything similar.

Does anyone here have any knowledge of the software development practices of any automakers and what they do to ensure safety and reliability? And is there anything else I can do to mitigate this risk (short of buying a very old car, which would have other safety downsides)?

[1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sudden_unintended_acceleration [2] http://spinroot.com/gerard/pdf/P10.pdf
